holidays.name: International Sloth Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to celebrating and raising awareness about sloths, the slow-moving and adorable mammals native to Central and South America. It's the perfect excuse to take it slow and appreciate the little things!
holidays.origin: International Sloth Day was conceived by sloth lovers and conservationists aiming to promote the protection of sloths and their rainforest habitats.
holidays.funFact: Sloths only poop once a week, and they climb down from the trees to do it—increasing their risk from predators!

holidays.name: Brandied Fruit Day
holidays.description: A delicious day to enjoy fruit soaked in brandy, a sweet and boozy treat often used in holiday desserts and festive dishes.
holidays.origin: This quirky food day celebrates the tradition of preserving fruits with brandy, which dates back centuries in European culinary practices.
holidays.funFact: Brandied cherries were once a popular garnish for cocktails, and some even say that soaking fruit in brandy helps preserve it for up to a year!

holidays.name: Evaluate Your Life Day
holidays.description: A somewhat serious but quirky holiday encouraging people to pause and thoughtfully assess their life’s direction and personal goals. Think of it as a weirdly timed self-help checkpoint.
holidays.origin: Created by life coaches and motivational speakers as a nudge for mid-fall reflection, helping people refocus before the end of the year.
holidays.funFact: Despite being a day for reflection, many people use Evaluate Your Life Day to create quirky vision boards or doodle their goals rather than meditate seriously!

holidays.name: National Pale Ale Day (USA)
holidays.description: A hoppy day to celebrate pale ales—beer styles known for their balance of malt and hop flavors, favored by craft beer aficionados everywhere.
holidays.origin: Craft beer enthusiasts established this day to promote pale ales and appreciate the art of brewing this distinctive beer variety.
holidays.funFact: The first pale ales in history were brewed with pale malt and gold “noble” hops, giving them a unique light color and complex flavor—quite the opposite of stereotypical darker beers!
